questions.question_text: Which protocol is used for setting up secure channels between two devices, typically in VPNs?

discussion.content:
ppp =point to point protocol (used in dial-up)
IPSEC =tunnelling protocol
PEM =file format used to store certificates
SET =possibly Secure Electronic Transaction https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_Electronic_Transaction

IPsec is a group of protocols that are used together to set up encrypted connections between devices. It helps keep data sent over public networks secure. IPsec is often used to set up VPNs, and it works by encrypting IP packets, along with authenticating the source where the packets come from.
Diff types of hash functions: MD5 (128). SHA-1 (SHA-160), SHA2 (SHA-256, SHA-512)
both sha1 and 2 produces 160 bit hash funtion
SHA-1: A 160-bit hash function which resembles the earlier MD5 algorithm.
It is C. SHA-1 according the official CEH Courseware.

according to https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6194
both sha#0 and sha#1 are 160-bit function

questions.question_text: Which of the following Secure Hashing Algorithm (SHA) produces a 160-bit digest from a message with a maximum length of (264-1) bits and resembles the MD5 algorithm?
When does the Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI-DSS) require organizations to perform external and internal penetration testing?

choices.C: At least once every two years and after any significant upgrade or modification
choices.B: At least once a year and after any significant upgrade or modification
choices.D: At least once every three years or after any significant upgrade or modification
choices.A: At least twice a year or after any significant upgrade or modification

discussion.content:
The original wording of Requirement 11.3 reads:

(Businesses must) Perform penetration testing at least once a year and after any significant infrastructure or application upgrade or modification (such as an operating system upgrade, a sub-network added to the environment, or a web server added to the environment). These penetration tests must include the following:

11.3.1 Network-layer penetration tests
11.3.2 Application-layer penetration tests

questions.question_text: If a tester is attempting to ping a target that exists but receives no response or a response that states the destination is unreachable, ICMP may be disabled and the network may be using TCP. Which other option could the tester use to get a response from a host using TCP?

discussion.content:
hping =linux based tool
tcping.exe =windows based tool able to check if given TCP port is open
traceroute and brodcast ping will use icmp
D is correct answer. Key here is "userland exploit" - jailbreak that allows user-level access without iBoot-level access

A userland exploit is a jailbreak that allows user-level access without iBoot-level access
According to EC Council" A bootrom exploit is a jailbreak that allows user-level access and iboot-level access. 
According to EC Council" A bootrom exploit is a jailbreak that allows user-level access and iboot-level access.
An iBoot exploit is a jailbreak that allows file system and iBoot access. Mobile Platform Hacking

What's a bootrom exploit? 
A jailbreak that allows user-level access with iBoot-level access
A userland exploit is a jailbreak that allows user-level access without iBoot-level access.
